comments: None
N/A
Zoom course w/ discussion, quizzes, readings, presentations over Zoom. Class size of around 11 students & 1 professor.
Mainly live, virtual discussions, readings, and lectures.
There were also weekly optional "Chinese Table" discussions on casual topics.
N/A
Virtual Office Hours

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: A greater appreciation for Chinese and a significantly improved ability to read, write, and comprehend.
I learned how to better read and write colloquial Chinese
I greatly improved my Chinese skills and cultural knowledge.

I learned new Chinese vocabulary and about Chinese culture and history. I also learned to write better Chinese essays and the differences between informal and formal Chinese diction. Our professor also taught us calligraphy over Zoom outside of class which I enjoyed.
This class helped me tremendously in improving my Chinese skills and Su Lao Shis stories are always very entertaining!

I greatly improved my Chinese proficiency, especially my speed of reading and processing. I was able to practice my speaking skills on the regular, which helped me become more fluent in my translations and responses. I noticed the greatest growth in the quality of my writing, through developing essays that were coherent, interesting, and descriptive. I also became more knowledgeable about aspects of Chinese culture and history, such as the different schools of thought and practices in daily life.
I learned a lot of new Chinese vocabulary, greatly improved my reading, reading, and speaking skills, and overall became better at Chinese.
I developed a greater understanding of the Chinese language and culture. I also improved my reading speed and increased my knowledge of phrases.
Strengthened knowledge of Chinese culture as well as reading, listening, and writing skills.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: It was a great course that was very interactive, welcoming, and push me to improve
Strengths are Su laoshi's interesting anecdotes and experiences, weakness is the late feedback.
The course was very engaging and informative.

I don't think there were many weaknesses to the course, I enjoyed that the class size was relatively small. There was a good distribution of material learned and I like that we weren't strictly focused on vocabulary/readings but had the opportunity to learn about Chinese culture and history.

I appreciated that, even with the virtual format, this course was very engaging and required students to be vocal each class. We took turns reading from the textbook, answering questions, and repeating key phrases. It was also unique that it still emphasized writing and traditional characters, which sometimes can be glossed over with our modern typing tools. Some may view this as a weakness, as sometimes the traditional characters didn't seem as crucial to learn, but I could understand that we learned them to recognize the words' historical roots. We learned Chinese very thoroughly, through speaking, writing, and listening, and it was clear that Su Laoshi was extremely knowledgeable and enthusiastic. The only critique I can think of is that the assignments and due dates could have been communicated more clearly, and further in advance.

Strengths are that Su Laoshi is extremely kind, engaging, and makes each class super fun. He's always bringing up interesting topics throughout class, teaching us both about the Chinese language and even some culture/history, and he really allows each student to participate in discussion and class. He was able to make even virtual classes a blast.

Strengths: Amount of coursework is just right. The work doesn't overload me but I also learn from each of the assignments I do and gain valuable language skills from writing essays and preparing for presentations. The stories and outside of textbook topics that the professor talks about are also interesting and makes it easy to engage in class.

Strengths: Curriculum is enriching, covering a multitude of topics of Chinese culture, while strengthening skills in Chinese in the process.
Weakness: Consider giving more frequent grade updates via Canvas.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: All were great and functioned as they should.
Everything was pretty good -- course translated well from in-person to virtual.
The virtual office hours were very helpful, and I felt that the engagement on Zoom was very good.
I'm a first-year and I'm not sure what this course would look like in-person, so I don't know that I'd be able to answer this question well, but I thought that it was fairly engaging.

The live format was successful in that we were still able to practice speaking Chinese together, which is a crucial component to any language class. It was harder, however, to try to learn words on the spot from Su Laoshi, since he didn't have a whiteboard or a method of sharing the written characters more clearly.

Each class was on Zoom. Students were called on by the teacher to either answer a question or read a passage. This was extremely effective because each student could participate a decent amount each class, and no time was wasted with using the raise hand function or anything like that.
Reading the text of the textbook out loud one by one helps with pronunciation. Calling someone different to answer each question also helps everyone participate in the class.

Succeeded: Office hours as well as live Chinese lectures were a success. Chinese Table was not a bad idea but could be more heavily promoted, it seemed to be under utilized and was a great opportunity to practice speaking the language casually.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes. Su Laoshi is amazing and the course goes through a lot of great material that challenges your reading, writing, and speaking abilities.
Chill Chinese class and interesting! Good chance to improve speaking skills.
I would recommend this course to another student because I improved my Chinese skills by a lot, and the class was also very engaging.
Yes, definitely.
Yes! Absolutely.

Yes, Su Laoshi is a wonderful and caring teacher who puts a lot of energy into this class. He truly loves sharing his knowledge and stories, and his frequent tangents are always very informative. He tries to get to know every student as a person, and gives thoughtful feedback to the writing assignments. I will say, though, sometimes the material from the book is a bit outdated--I've shared topics with my parents, and they are surprised that the contents come from many years ago. Nonetheless, you learn a lot about Chinese culture and important vocabulary to talk about everyday life. I just wish we could have been in-person, so we all could have wrapped dumplings together at the end!

I definitely would! Not only is Su Laoshi one of the best profs I've had, but the material was difficult enough that I could see improvement in my skills each week, but not too hard that it was discouraging. I enjoyed the various readings on many different topics, as well as essay topics that ranged across many different subjects.

Absolutely!!! Su Laoshi is an awesome teacher and will elevate your Chinese to a whole new level. You'll learn cool idioms and phrases, interesting facts about the Chinese culture, and watch your reading, listening, and writing skills improve throughout the semester.
